G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: The parties are subject to the jurisdiction of the **Weston Probate and Family Court** (the “Court”) pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and G.L. c. 215, § 6, as this matter concerns custody and parenting time of a minor child who is a resident of the Commonwealth.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: The parties are subject to the jurisdiction of the **Weston Probate and Family Court** (the “Court”) pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and G.L. c. 215, § 6, as this matter concerns custody and parenting time of a minor child who is a resident of the Commonwealth.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: The parties are subject to the jurisdiction of the **Weston Probate and Family Court** (the “Court”) pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and G.L. c. 215, § 6, as this matter concerns custody and parenting time of a minor child who is a resident of the Commonwealth.

*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.proposition: Since entry of the 2018 Judgment, there have been multiple, substantial, and continuing changes in circumstances that affect the welfare and best interests of Emily and that warrant modification of custody and parenting time.
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns modification of custody and parenting time based on substantial and continuing changes affecting a child’s welfare and best interests since a 2018 judgment. Schuler v. Schuler addresses modification of alimony and child support obligations based on a material change in financial circumstances of the payor spouse, not custody, parenting time, or a post-2018 context. While it recites the general standard that a material change of circumstances is required for modification, it does not discuss custody/best-interests modifications, so it does not substantively support the specific proposition cited.
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. Robbins v. Robbins, 343 Mass. 247, 249 (1961). Hinds v. Hinds, 329 Mass. 190, 191-192 (1952). In this case, the judge held that Chester did not prove the requisite change of circumstances.”

*Pearson v. Pearson*, 52 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Since entry of the 2018 Judgment, there have been multiple, substantial, and continuing changes in circumstances that affect the welfare and best interests of Emily and that warrant modification of custody and parenting time.
*Pearson v. Pearson*, 52 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The proposition concerns modification of custody and parenting time based on substantial and continuing changes affecting a child’s best interests. Pearson v. Pearson deals exclusively with modification of child support (and related attorney’s fees) under G.L. c. 208, § 28, not with custody or parenting time. While the opinion mentions that modification requires analysis of changed circumstances and the best interests of the children, it does so only in the support context and does not provide authority for modifying custody or parenting time based on post‑judgment changes since 2018 or otherwise.
*Pearson v. Pearson*, 52 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “The statute governing support modification requires an analysis of both the changed circumstances of the parties and the best interests of the children. See G. L. c. 208, § 28. When setting an amount of support, judges are granted discretion to award sums beyond the guideline amount where, as here, one or both of the parents exceed certain income levels.”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: The improvement in Mother’s work schedule, income, and housing situation constitutes a **substantial and material change** from the circumstances that existed at the time of the 2018 Judgment, directly bearing on her capacity to exercise more parenting time and to share or assume increased physical custody.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns standards for relocation/removal under G.L. c. 208, § 30 and the best-interests analysis when parents share joint physical custody. It does not address modification of custody or parenting time based on a parent’s improved work schedule, income, or housing, nor does it discuss what constitutes a substantial and material change in circumstances for a modification petition. The only reference to “substantial change in circumstances” is within a quoted ALI provision about relocation itself, not parental improvements in circumstances or increased parenting time/custody.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt:
The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002) ... state in pertinent part:
“(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances ... only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce] ...”
...
“(4) When a relocation constituting changed circumstances ... renders it impractical to maintain the same proportion of custodial responsibility to each parent, the court should modify the parenting plan in accordance with the child’s best interests ...”

*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.proposition: The improvement in Mother’s work schedule, income, and housing situation constitutes a **substantial and material change** from the circumstances that existed at the time of the 2018 Judgment, directly bearing on her capacity to exercise more parenting time and to share or assume increased physical custody.
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns relocation, paternity establishment, and the statutory rights of an unmarried mother as the sole legal parent prior to adjudication of paternity. It does not address modification standards, “substantial and material change” analysis, or how improvements in a parent’s work schedule, income, or housing affect parenting time or physical custody. The cited text is therefore not authority for the claimed proposition about changes in a mother’s circumstances justifying increased parenting time or custody.
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.relevant_excerpt: “After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate.”

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: As children grow, their needs, schedules, relationships, and capacities to benefit from different parenting arrangements change; this Court recognizes that a prior custody and parenting‑time order may become inappropriate or unworkable over time.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on standards for modifying custody (material and substantial change in circumstances) and for removal under the Yannas ‘real advantage’ test. It does not discuss developmental changes in children over time, evolving needs or schedules, or the idea that prior parenting-time orders may naturally become inappropriate as children grow. Instead, it stresses the stability of the existing arrangement and the absence of any post‑divorce changes warranting modification, which cuts against the claimed proposition.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “There is nothing in the findings or the record before us to indicate that anything occurred after the divorce that so altered the circumstances of the parties as to warrant a change in custodial arrangements which, on all of the uncontested evidence, had been in place with no ill effect on the child since the parties’ separation in October, 1995.”

*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.proposition: As children grow, their needs, schedules, relationships, and capacities to benefit from different parenting arrangements change; this Court recognizes that a prior custody and parenting‑time order may become inappropriate or unworkable over time.
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on an initial custody determination and a contemporaneous removal request, not on modification of an existing custody or parenting-time order based on changed circumstances over time. While the court acknowledges that divorce inevitably brings change for children, it does not discuss or recognize that prior custody/parenting orders may become inappropriate or unworkable as children grow. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about later modification as children’s needs evolve.
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change … and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.proposition: While a child’s preference is **not controlling**, Massachusetts courts recognize that a mature child’s genuine and reasonable preference is an important factor in determining best interests, especially where it is consistent with the child’s emotional needs and stability.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that the preference of an eleven-year-old is not given decisive (controlling) weight but is a factor to be considered, and it notes the child’s clearly stated affection and preference as part of the best-interests analysis. The court also suggests, on remand, that given the child’s increased age, the judge may appropriately re-interview him about his preference, reinforcing that a mature child’s genuine preference is an important, though not controlling, factor in determining custody and best interests.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.relevant_excerpt: “Although the boy was described in testimony as ‘a really bright student,’ we note that the preference of an eleven-year-old is not given decisive weight, although it is a factor to be considered. See Custody of a Minor, 383 Mass. 595, 602 (1981); Baird v. Attorney Gen., 371 Mass. 741, 753 (1977); Bellotti v. Baird, 443 U.S. 622 (1979); Stone v. Duffy, 219 Mass. 178, 182 (1914); Bak v. Bak, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 617 (1987). … As almost three years have gone by… it may be appropriate for the judge to interview the child again as to his preference…”}

*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: While a child’s preference is **not controlling**, Massachusetts courts recognize that a mature child’s genuine and reasonable preference is an important factor in determining best interests, especially where it is consistent with the child’s emotional needs and stability.
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The opinion is lengthy and detailed about best-interests analysis, stability, bonding, sibling relationships, and competing adoption plans, but it does not address, even in passing, the role of a child’s stated preference in custody or adoption decisions. Hugo is four years old and there is no discussion of eliciting or weighing his wishes, nor any general statement about how a mature child’s preference should be treated. Because the case never speaks to child preference at all, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition that a mature child’s reasonable preference is an important factor in the best-interests analysis.
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt: "Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The 'best interests of a child' is a question that presents the trial judge 'with a classic example of a discretionary decision.'"

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.proposition: While a child’s preference is **not controlling**, Massachusetts courts recognize that a mature child’s genuine and reasonable preference is an important factor in determining best interests, especially where it is consistent with the child’s emotional needs and stability.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses best-interests analysis and factors like each parent’s role as primary caretaker, the children’s bonds, and minimizing disruption, but it never mentions the children’s wishes or preference as a factor. There is no discussion of interviewing the children, assessing their maturity, or weighing their stated custodial preferences. Because the case does not address child preference at all, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition that a mature child’s reasonable custodial preference is an important, though not controlling, best-interests factor.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.relevant_excerpt: In deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare… The judge found the wife has been the “primary nurturing parent” and “primary caretaker” and that the children have the “strongest bond” with their mother. These factors are highly significant for the welfare of the children, and are thus critical considerations for the judge in deciding on a custodial arrangement which minimizes disruption and fosters a healthy environment for the growth and development of the children.

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The Court’s primary concern in custody and parenting‑time determinations is the **best interests of the child**.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly frames custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10(a) in terms of what is in “the best interests of the child” and describes that standard as the long‑standing touchstone in Massachusetts custody law. The court reviews the probate judge’s decision by asking whether all relevant factors in determining the child’s best interests were weighed, confirming that the primary concern in custody and parenting-time matters is the child’s best interests.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “Section 10 (a) gives a probate judge the power to award custody of nonmarital children ‘to the mother or the father or to them jointly ... as may be appropriate in the best interests of the child.’ … In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… [T]he ‘best interests’ standard … has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation… ‘the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern.’”
